;

;Russian sinologist Yegov (Игорь Aлександрович Егоров) passed away. He was one year younger than me. He was born in 1953 and left before he was seventy. According to our Chinese concept, it was a bit early. Maybe he had a bad life and stayed up late for a long time to translate, which damaged his health. My friend Mr. Liu Xianping from the Writers Association told me that he suffers from diabetes, which is so severe that he is about to have his limbs amputated.

;

;In the history of Sino-Russian cultural exchanges, Yegov can be regarded as a very contributory figure. First, as the Chinese editor of the Soviet State Literature Publishing House, he devoted great efforts to introducing Chinese literature to the Soviet Union and later to Russia for decades. Secondly, as a Russian sinologist, he translated the works of some writers during the May 4th Movement period such as Mao Dun. Later, he focused mainly on contemporary Chinese literature. The writers he translated included Su Tong, Yu Hua, Mo Yan, Bi Feiyu, etc. He has also translated some English works, but, in his own words, it is to earn royalties and support the Chinese literature he loves to translate.

;

;For me, Yegov is my colleague in work. In terms of business, we can provide each other with practical and useful help and solve problems on the manuscript. At the same time, we are also friends who can open our hearts and exchange ideas, even though our views are sometimes inconsistent or even diametrically opposed on certain issues.

;

;;

;

;Photo taken during Ye Guofu's first visit to Beijing in the 1990s. ;(Photo provided by the author);

;

;;Ten Days in Beijing;

;

;Ye Guo and I The first time I met my husband was in March 1990. As the Chinese editor of the Leningrad branch of the Soviet State Literature Publishing House, he came to visit the People’s Literature Publishing House where I worked. At that time, Sino-Soviet relations had just begun to normalize. I remember that after the "Selected Novels of Rasputin" that I edited was published in 1982, I gave the author several donated books at the request of the Soviet Embassy. I sent the gift letter to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as required, and they handed it over to the Soviet Embassy. In 2006, Rasputin came to Beijing Foreign Studies University for a meeting. He told me that he had only heard that a collection of his novels had been published in China, but he had never seen it. When Sholokhov passed away in 1984, researcher Sun Meiling of the Institute of Foreign Languages ​​and Literatures of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences wrote a short message, but there was no place to publish it. The same is true in the publishing industry. It was not until 1986 and 1987 that the leaders of the Soviet State Literature Publishing House and the People's Literature Publishing House realized mutual visits. In 1989, when our older generation editors Sun Shengwu, Jiang Lu, Xu Leiran, Chen Siyong, and Lu Yongfu visited the Soviet Union, they also visited their publishing house. This time they came to visit for ten days. The formal talks were translated by old comrade Mr. Cheng Wen. I was only responsible for accompanying them on sightseeing and shopping, so everyone was relatively relaxed and casual, talking and laughing. I no longer went to the Soviet Union in the early 1980s. That kind of nervousness at the embassy.

;

;Four editors came to this visit from the Soviet State Literature Publishing House: Director of the Foreign Literature Editorial Office Klimova, English editor; Chinese editor Yaroslavsky, an old comrade who is over 60 years old , has translated many Chinese classical literary works, and he translated the poems in the Russian version of "Jin Ping Mei"; and Yura Ilyashin, a young Chinese editor who came to China in 1984 as a reporter for the TASS News Agency and reformed After the opening up, he set up a company in China and published the newspaper "Hand to Hand". These three people are all from the Moscow headquarters, while Yegov is from the Leningrad branch, and his name on his business card is the director of the editorial office. It seemed that he was not very familiar with the three people at the head office, so I took more care of him and spent a longer time chatting with him.

;

;During the conversation, I learned that Yegov, Yura and I both started learning each other's language in the early 1970s, shortly after the "Zhenbao Island Incident". The purpose is self-evident and everyone knows it well. I told Ye Guofu that in 1969 I was an educated youth, and the Heilongjiang Production and Construction Corps station where I was located was only 95 kilometers away from Zhenbao Island. His eyes widened in surprise. I continued to tell him: Back then, there was an old high school senior in the company who taught everyone how to speak Russian every morning. I remember the first sentence I learned was: "Raise your hands!" He was startled at first, and was stunned for a moment, but he immediately became alert. Di replied in Chinese: "Hand in the gun and not kill!" We both laughed.

;

;Another reason why Yegov and I had more contact during those ten days was that our speaking skills were pretty much the same. Yura was stationed in Beijing in 1984 when he was a reporter. I met him at the embassy. His listening and speaking abilities were better than ours. I talked with Yegov. He rushed to speak Chinese and I rushed to speak Russian. He only spoke his own language when he really didn't understand. It seemed that he was afraid of losing the opportunity to exercise and suffer a disadvantage. Yegov is a shy man. He blushes when seeing our old comrades. He speaks softly and has an elegant manner. He is very Leningrader and not as flamboyant as a Muscovite.

;

;When they came, they were very interested in shopping, but shopping is my weakness. Every day after get off work, I would memorize Russian words that I might need the next day until late at night. Despite careful preparation, there were still many troubles. One morning, the four of them said seriously that they wanted to buy a must-buy food entrusted by a friend. It was round and colorful in shape and would grow bigger when fried in oil. Yaroslavsky also ridiculously made a sudden explosion with his hands, and made a "pop" sound from his mouth at the same time. The more vividly they described it, the richer my imagination became. I couldn't figure it out, so I had to lead them into the Dongdan Vegetable Market. We divided the troops into four groups, each of them holding an aisle, and searched carefully. After a while, Klimova's cry of surprise came. I went over to take a look and it turned out to be shrimp crackers. In order to avoid such trouble and lively atmosphere, I invited Mr. Gao Mang when I visited the Great Wall. He spoke very well. The four guests were extremely excited to see Gao Mang, as if meeting old friends in a foreign land, and they poured out all the words they had been holding in their hearts for several days. Yegov told me that Mr. Gao Mang was very famous in the Soviet Union.

;

;The main result of their visit was to confirm the publishing plans of both parties in the next three years: Su Fang published "Nie Haihua", "Selected Poems of the Song Dynasty", "Dream of Red Mansions" and selected works by Guo Moruo, Lao She and Mao Dun; our publisher Published several volumes of "Collected Works of Tolstoy", "Collected Works of Pushkin", "Selected Works of Turgenev" and an "Encyclopedic Dictionary of Literature". The most important thing is that the two publishing houses will each publish a collection of contemporary novels from the other, and the selections will be recommended by the other. The People's Literature Publishing House completed this project in the second year, but the Soviet State Literature Publishing House failed to publish it until it was disbanded.

;

;My personal gain is that my hearing has improved. They tell Soviet jokes every day, and sometimes I can’t believe my ears. In my impression, Yegov didn't say a word, and always maintained a gentlemanly attitude, as if he was listening.

;

;;

;

;Yegov and the author of this article in front of the People's Literature Publishing House. ;(Photo provided by the author);

;

;;Three-month internship;

;

;1991 In May, I was dispatched by the Press and Publication Administration to work as an intern editor at the Soviet State Literary Publishing House. Klimova and Yura Ilyashin, who had just visited our publisher in 1990, were responsible for receiving me and were very warm to me. They also held a welcome meeting for the external editors' office, met with their leaders at all levels, and visited their publishing house. , they treat me like a newly assigned colleague. By the way, this publishing house, especially the configuration of language staff in the foreign literature editing room, is very similar to our publishing house, except that there are more editors in the Indian language group. After I came back and talked about this situation, President Chen Wanchun said: It should be said that we are just like them. President Feng Xuefeng visited this publishing house in 1951, and our publishing house adopted the configuration of their publishing houses when it was first established.

;

;On June 19, according to their arrangements, we arrived in Leningrad. As the head of the branch, Yegov received us and accompanied us on literary sightseeing every day - many writers in the history of literature have left their footprints in Leningrad. Yegov is a native of Leningrad, and he also knows many stories about the corners. . After visiting Tsarskoye Selo on June 24, while resting on the lawn in front of the square, Yegov and I had a debate about the October Revolution and socialism. We spoke Russian for a while and Chinese for a while. The accompanying staff laughed. . Yegov told me some social situations, which surprised me. When I was eating in the cafeteria of the Moscow headquarters, I heard someone say that I thought it was because of my poor hearing and I didn't understand, but I always felt that something happened. I asked Yura, and his answer was vague and obviously prevaricating, unlike Yegov's straightforwardness. At that time, the Soviet Union was experiencing painful struggles before its death.

;

;On August 16, 1991, we ended our three-month internship in the Soviet Union and returned to Beijing. Four days later, the "8·19" incident that shocked the world occurred in Moscow's Red Square. The Soviet Union collapsed on December 25 of the same year.

;

;;

;

;Photographed in Yegov's office in 1992. ;(Photo provided by the author);

;

;;One year of further study;

;

;November 1992 In August, I returned to Leningrad again, this time being sent by the State Education Commission to study for a year. At this time, Leningrad was being renamed St. Petersburg. The first sign to be replaced was the Leningrad Railway Station sign. I specially rushed to watch it. Looking at the slowly falling "Leningrad" sign, I felt extremely complicated.

;

;Before I settled down at Leningrad University, Yegov came to see me. Seeing that I was living in a crowded four-person room, he was a little embarrassed, as if he had made such a bad arrangement for me. But within a few days, I was transferred to a single room. One day in the lobby on the first floor, the dormitory administrator stopped me and insisted on chatting with me. He first introduced himself: a member of the Soviet Communist Party and one of the first pilots after the outbreak of the Great Patriotic War. However, he was quickly shot down and transferred to the hospital for treatment. When he recovered and was ready to return to the sky, the war ended. Then he said that he respected me very much and knew that I had introduced many Russian writers to China. He even knew that I had translated the works of Semyonov. This writer was well-known in the Soviet Union and had written works about the Soviet-German spy war. After questioning me carefully, I found out that it was Yegov who told him so that he could change me to a better room. This veteran administrator was cunning, selfish, and did some ridiculous things, but he gave me a lot of help during my year of studying abroad. I am very grateful to him, and even more grateful to Yegov.

;

;The publishing house where Yegov worked was located in the most beautiful and lively area on Nevsky Prospekt, on the top floor of the St. Petersburg Bookstore. This building, built in the 18th century, is opposite the famous Kazan Church, so it welcomes a large number of tourists from all over the world every day. As one of the largest bookstores in Europe, St. Petersburg Bookstore not only sells the latest books in Russia and various foreign publications, but also a variety of cultural supplies and souvenirs. It also often holds various book fairs, book clubs, new book launches and author signings. Book signing.

;

;The Leningrad University where I have classes every day is right by the Neva River. I can walk across the bridge to Nevsky Prospekt. If I take the subway, it is just one stop away, so I often come to this bookstore. As a publisher, I like it here. Besides, Yegov is upstairs. When you are tired, you can go to his office to sit, drink hot water and smoke a cigarette. There are benches in the corridor where you can lie down. Most of the people in their editorial office knew me, and they entertained me when Yegov was away. Ye Guofu was obsessed with translation at that time and always looked forward to my going. Sometimes he knew that I had gone to the bookstore but not upstairs, and he still didn't understand. Almost every time he went, he would take out a few pages of paper prepared in advance, with problems to be solved written on them. There was a space after each question for me to write my opinion, and I just had to rewrite it into sentences he could understand. Ye Guofu is a very smart man. This way, we can avoid misunderstandings due to oral expressions and leave the words in black and white for him to ponder carefully.

;

;I remember that I helped him do one thing, which was the project signed by the two publishers in 1990 - each other published a collection of contemporary novels from each other, and the task of the Russian version of the collection of contemporary Chinese novels was handed over to him. Yegov. At that time, the Chinese manuscripts recommended by the Chinese side were piled on his desk. According to the editing style, each writer had a biography. These biographies were all handwritten by the writers themselves, with different number of words and different styles and formats. Some even included the words "Cultural Revolution". "The allegro lyrics created by Zhongzai's publicity team were also included. Lao Ye was confused and asked me for help with a grimace. I rewrote it into a hundred words. Lao Ye understood and was very grateful. It took me some time and effort so I remember. Ye Guofu mentioned this matter several times when he came to Beijing and felt sorry for me because the book was not published in the end.

;

;At that time, he had finished translating Su Tong's "Wives and Concubines" and asked me to "correct" him. I have not read this novel, but I read it carefully in order to revise Yegov's translation. Regarding the serious errors in his translation, I only corrected them without explaining them. Instead, I raised objections to his criteria for selecting the translation. I said to him: What the author describes is a very special kind of abnormal life in China and does not have universal typical significance. Furthermore, after being translated into another language, a lot of essence has been lost, which does not reflect the level of contemporary Chinese literary creation. I suggested that he translate "There's a Snowstorm Tonight" by Liang Xiaosheng. It's on the recommendation list and I've read it. It's very good. But he said: The content described in this novel is very similar to Khrushchev's Siberian reclamation, and Russian readers will not like it.

;

;Yegov worked very hard on translation at that time. In addition to achieving his own lofty goals, there was also a very practical reason. In St. Petersburg in 1993, life was difficult for ordinary people. My teacher told me that sometimes wages are not paid on time. When you get rubles, you have to change them into dollars immediately, and then into rubles when you use them. When we first went there, it seemed that one dollar was exchanged for 300 rubles, and a month later it was exchanged for 400. Half a year later, when I went to Moscow University, I actually got 1,300 rubles in the Vietnamese dormitory. Mr. Qi Yide, who translated "Sanyan Erpai", was a famous sinologist of the older generation. She called one night and said she had not bought any bread. I would take a short detour to school and pass by her house. Sometimes I would buy some bread or something, hang it on her doorknob, and call her to let her know.

;

;;Two Unforgettable Things;

;

;Ye Guofu earned extra money by translating to supplement his family income. From my contact with him, I deeply felt that he was a very family-oriented man who treated his wife and children very much like a good Chinese man. He is also sincere and enthusiastic in helping people, and will go all out when you need him. On August 14, 1993, I received a long-distance call from China from Li Yuxia, director of the foreign literature editorial office of our newspaper. She asked me to immediately find a solution to the problem of "Destruction", "Young Guards" and "Quiet Don". There is a copyright issue because there are domestic publishers who took action before us. From the tone of her voice and the speed of her speech, I could tell that the situation was critical. These three books are the standing books of our society, especially the latter two. They have been reprinted every year since the early 1980s. As soon as we joined the Berne Convention, publishers came to snatch us up. As the editor in charge of these three books, I was naturally impatient. I found Yegov on the same day and explained the situation to him. The next day he helped me contact Sholokhov’s copyright heir, his daughter Svetlana. She told me that she had indeed received an application from a Chinese publisher, but had not signed it yet. She also told me that Sholokhov once had the opportunity to visit China, but it was a pity that he did not make the trip. Svetlana promised that the copyright would be given to People's Literature Publishing House. From her words, I felt that Yegov had talked to her beforehand, and she knew everything, so I didn’t need to waste any words. Two days later, I went to the Moscow Literary Publishing House. Yura helped me contact Fadeev’s widow. Her answer reassured me: “My sample books are all published by the People’s Literature Publishing House. Of course, this book is also Published by you." The thing that made me panic was solved smoothly with the help of two friends.

;

;There is another thing that makes me very grateful to Yegov. In September 1993, my wife was coming to Leningrad to visit relatives. There were no mobile phones at that time, and it was difficult to make long-distance calls. Somehow, Ye Guov became the hub of communication between me and my wife, the "mouthpiece" for information, probably because there was a phone in his office that could make international long distance calls. He seemed to be an official at that time. I checked the diary from that year and found that Ye Guofu came to my dormitory five or six times that month. The last time was at eight o'clock in the evening, telling my wife the time of departure from Beijing and arrival in Moscow. Why didn't you tell me over the phone? Maybe it was because I was afraid that I wouldn’t understand and misunderstood, so I talked about it in person and wrote it down on a piece of paper. It shows how serious and reliable he is.

;

;A few days after his wife arrived, Yegov invited us to his home. He even picked us up at the subway station that day. In fact, I have been to his house many times and the route is very familiar to me. When he entered, his wife dressed up to welcome him very warmly and set a table full of delicious food. An interesting thing happened before dinner started. I was browsing his collection of books in Yegov's room. Yegov, who was originally translating for the host and guest, walked in quietly, patted my shoulder gently, and pointed outside. I looked over and saw two ladies sitting on the sofa who didn't understand each other's language at all. They were beaming and talking animatedly. Yegov and I looked at each other for a moment and almost laughed. We had a great time that day, and the two ladies hugged each other at the subway entrance before parting, like good sisters who have been friends for many years.

;

;;

;

;In 2012, Ye Guofu (second from left) and Mo Yan (third from left) met at the People's Literature Publishing House. ;(Photo provided by the author);

;

;;See you again in twenty years;

;

; In the first few years after returning to China, I still communicated with Ye Guofu and asked someone to take care of me. Later, we lost contact. Around 2000, someone told me that the original Soviet State Literature Publishing House was dissolved and no longer existed. Until 2012, a colleague told me that Ye Guofu came to me online and said that he would come to Beijing to hold an international seminar for sinologists. Twenty years later, we met at the hotel where he was staying. He held my hand and said that I have not aged, and I held his hand and said that he still looks the same. We all know we are telling lies. We resumed our conversation the next day in my office. I showed him the Russian literary works I had edited and published over the past 20 years, and he told me about his journey in the past 20 years and the works he had translated. He said that he had been reading Mo Yan's novels for several years, found a feeling for them, and started translating them. When talking about his experience, he also said, like some people, that Mo Yan's novels were influenced by Western "magic realism".

;

;I told him that most Chinese writers create their own works. As far as the writers I have read, I don’t think any of them have been influenced by foreign writers. If we talk about influence, it is also the region where they were born and their innate personal personalities. These two factors determine their storytelling methods and characteristics. For example, if I ask Mo Yan, he is actually telling the story of the land and water where he was raised in Gaomi, Shandong Province, using his unique storytelling method, just like his fellow Shandong fellow Pu Songling used his method to tell the story of "Liao Zhai Zhi". "different" same. Their place in Shandong has this long literary tradition and is rich in this kind of literature. Yegov seems to understand vaguely, but I feel that our conversation today seems to be a continuation of the conversation in Leningrad about the criteria for selecting translation works.

;

;I showed him the contemporary Russian literary works published by our agency in the past ten years, including more than a dozen novels and four short story collections, involving more than 70 writers, including those who became famous in the 1950s. There are new works by the old writer Graning, works by the world-famous Rasputin in the 1960s, and award-winning young writers in the 1980s and 1990s. He was very surprised when he saw it. The translated works of Russian contemporary literature published by our publishing house were as good as the translated works of Chinese contemporary literature published in Russia. Probably touching his sadness, he vomited his bitterness to me, saying how difficult it is to publish a Chinese literary work in Russia, not to mention that China has a huge readership of Russian literature, and all the publishing houses in Russia are now He founded a private publishing house and only focused on profits...

;

;On August 21, 2012, Ye Guofu called and told him that he would meet with Mr. Mo Yan tomorrow and asked me to attend. The location could be in my office. Of course I agree. Mr. Mo Yan came earlier the next day. He gave me two of his books, and I gave me a set of "The Quiet Don River" that I edited. Mr. Mo Yan is a very down-to-earth, sincere and natural person. He does not seem like the kind of person who hides his hidden agenda. In fact, I met him, I remember it was at the Strindberg Seminar at Peking University, and he even gave a speech.

;

;I chatted with Mr. Mo Yan for a while, and then Ye Guofu came. The two of them didn't seem to know each other very well, and they were a little reserved at first. Yegov was not a good talker. Fortunately, I soon let go. Mr. Mo Yan is still very good at leading the topic and livening up the atmosphere. At that time, I thought Mo Yan was quite eloquent and thought he could tell stories. I heard Mr. Feng Jicai tell a story. It was when he was revising a manuscript at the People's Literature Publishing House. At that time, he asked to turn off the lights, saying that it would be more effective. So I think most writers have the talent to tell stories. The topic that day basically revolved around Mr. Mo Yan’s creations. The president, Comrade Guan Shiguang, came for more than half an hour. Yegov didn't talk much. He talked about Chinese literature, especially the "experience" of contemporary Chinese literature in Russia, and how difficult it was to publish his translation of Mo Yan's works... I also know something about this situation. I participated in several book fairs and book ordering events in Moscow and Leningrad. I never saw a single Chinese literary work, but occasionally came across one or two books with a touch of "Kung Fu". . By the end of the day, everyone was still chatting happily. I checked the diary of that day: "We chatted from 2 pm to 6 pm, and then had dinner at Jiuyefu Restaurant opposite the publishing house until 8:30."

;

;The day before returning to China, we went together During dinner, Ye Guofu told me that Mr. Liu Zhenyun also wanted to translate a few of his works and asked me to express my opinion. I said: "You know, there is an old saying in China: The writing is like the person. Mo Yan is from Shandong, his writing is straightforward, and he tells stories. Liu Zhenyun is from Henan, his writing is melodramatic, and he has the unique humor of Henan people. His works are exquisite It is taste, and taste is difficult to translate. For example, there is a sentence in Lu Xun's "The Story in the Hair": "Most of the families lazily walked out a citizen." The word "pace" and "国" in it have been translated , is boring. Another example is your translation of "Big Breasts, Wide Butts". If a Russian writer who has never seen the original work is translated into Chinese based on your translation, it will probably be translated into "Big Breasts, Wide Butts". ", what's the taste?" I suddenly realized something was wrong and couldn't help laughing. Ye Guofu seemed to have realized something, and he laughed out loud. I told him again that when I was an intern at the Moscow Literary Publishing House in 1991, they asked me many questions about the translation of Lao She's works and "Dream of Red Mansions", mostly about the "meaning" behind the words. I also told him about the "Water Margin" (Russian-Chinese version of the Greater China Library), which I was responsible for publishing. I carefully compared the problems found in Luo Gaoshou's translation, and wanted to further prove that what is lost when the two languages ​​are exchanged is the essence. Mainly This is because some words and expressions in Chinese are not found in Russian. Choose carefully.

;

;;The last meeting;

;

;The last time I met Yegov was on August 28, 2014, at the "Chinese-Russian Literature Translation" held at the Russian Embassy Publishing Project" meeting. There were a lot of people that day, and Yegov suddenly dragged the Russian writer Yesin to me, jokingly saying that he wanted to go through the back door: Yesin wanted his "Death of Giants" to be published by the People's Literature Publishing House. Yesin is a famous Russian writer and the dean of the Gorky Academy of Literature, and this novel is among the books recommended by Russia. So I obtained the consent of Liu Guohui, the leader of the society who came to the meeting with me, and called Mr. Liu Xianping from the Writers Association and the copyright association on the spot. Mr. Zhang Hongbo, the director-general and the person in charge of the "Mutual Translation Project" held a small meeting with Ye Xin and Ye Guofu and decided that "Death of Giants" would be published by our publisher and translated by Liu Xianping.

;

;Probably we are not the only publishing house that works on-site like ours. The venue was always noisy, and Yegov and I never had time to talk alone. When it was about to end, Ye Guofu hurriedly pulled me to a quiet corner and told me excitedly that the Chinese Writers Association gave him a large sum of money, which was enough for him to focus on translation in a few years without having to worry about making a living. . Looking at his slightly moist eyes, I was also very happy. I knew that his life had not been easy over the years.

;

;Rest in peace, Igor.
